I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the Secondary 
Education Sector Investment Program.1
 
 
2. 
The  proposed  investment  program  will  support  the  government’s  reform  of  secondary 
education  (grades  6–12)  into  a  system  that  builds  the  foundation  for  a  skilled  labor  force  and 
prepares  youths  to  meet  the  requirements  of  a  rapidly  developing  economy.  It  will  support 
advanced teaching and learning programs that use information and communication technology 
(ICT), as well as prevocational and vocational programs, teacher development, and examination 
reforms.  It  will  promote  gender-equitable  and  pro-poor  stipends  for  students.  It  will  help 
establish more decentralized and efficient allocation and use of resources, as well as strengthen 
sector performance monitoring. The investment program will build upon the ongoing Secondary 
Education  Sector  Development  Program 2  and  the  Second  Teaching  Quality  Improvement 
Project.3 It will further benefit from the experience of the Third Primary Education Development 
Project (PEDP III), which uses disbursement-linked indicators (DLIs).4 The investment program 
links  disbursement  to  the  achievement  of  key  results.  It  will  further  support  the  transition  to  a 
sector-wide approach.5
 

    

II. 

THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 

 
A. 
 

Rationale 

1. 

Macroeconomic and Sector Context   

 
3. 
The Bangladesh economy has grown rapidly at about 6% annually since 2003, up from 
5%  in  the  1990s.  The  poverty  headcount  index  declined  sharply  from  57%  in  1992  to  31%  in 
2010.  Social  indicators  have  improved  significantly,  particularly  for  women.  Bangladesh  has 
achieved gender parity in primary and secondary education participation since 2000. Women’s 
labor  force  participation  grew  from  26%  in  2003  to  36%  in  2010.  Bangladesh  has  a  declining 
dependency ratio of 54%, indicating an increasing share of working-age population in the next 
decade.  Economic  and  social  progress  coupled  with  a  demographic  dividend  creates  an 
important  opportunity  to  invest  in  human  capital  to  further  accelerate  economic  growth  and 
poverty reduction. Seizing this opportunity would  significantly help the country meet its goal of 
becoming a middle-income country by 2021.  
 
4. 
However,  Bangladesh  has  a  challenge  as  2  million  new  entrants  join  the  labor  market 
annually. Informal employment accounts for 89% of all employment, most of it underpaid daily 
wage  labor.  70%  of  informal  workers  have  no  education  or  only  primary  education. They  earn 
less than formal workers.6
 Workers with at least secondary schooling comprise 13% of the total

 2 

 

employment and 41% of formal employment. The low skills base of the Bangladesh labor force 
constrains  productivity  growth  and  limits  economic  diversification.  On  the  one  hand,  the 
economy  needs  to  generate  employment  that  is  productive  and  requires  skilled  labor.  On  the 
other hand, Bangladesh needs to invest more in education to transform the rising working-age 
population into a productive human resource base.  
     
5. 
School  education  performance.  Bangladesh  has  made  remarkable  progress  in 
education: (i) completion rates for primary education (grades 1–5) increased from 53% in 2005 
to 70% in 2011; (ii) gross enrollment in secondary education (grades 6–10) increased from 46% 
in  2005  to  61%  in  2011,  such  that  11  million  students  are  now  enrolled  in  either  general 
secondary schools or madrasahs (Islamic religious schools); (iii) gender parity in enrollment has 
been achieved up to grade 10; and (iv) the pass rate for the secondary school certificate (grade 
10) rose from 53% in 2005 to 82% in 2011 and for the higher secondary certificate (grade 12) 
from 59% to 75%. These results are due to sustained government reform to enhance the quality 
of  education,  provide  stipends,  and  expand  school  infrastructure.  Nongovernment  providers 
have  played  key  roles  in  rapidly  expanding  the  provision  of  secondary  education,  as  98%  of 
secondary schools are run by private providers and receive a government subsidy in the form of 
a monthly payment order for teacher salaries.   
 
6. 
Despite commendable achievement, Bangladesh has a formidable task ahead in making 
secondary education more efficient, equitable, and relevant to the economy’s needs. Only 46% 
of  students  complete  all  5  years  of  secondary  education.  Girls  drop  out  more  than  boys  after 
grade  9.  The  grade  9  survival  rate  in  2011  was  61%  for  boys  and  55%  for  girls.  Secondary 
education graduates have difficulty finding jobs relevant to their qualifications because they lack 
the cognitive and behavioral skills required by employers. Low efficiency and lack of relevance 
reflect  poor  teaching  quality,  the  limited  use  of  modern  teaching  methodologies  that  tap  ICT, 
and  weak  linkage  between  education  and  the  labor  market.  The  public  examination  system 
does  not  adequately  measure  learning  outcomes.  Access  to  high-quality  education  is 
inequitable,  as  no common  quality  standard  applies  across  all  types  of  schools.  Madrasahs  in 
particular  lack  capable  teachers,  adequate  school  infrastructure,  and  teaching  equipment. 
Poverty and sociocultural barriers  are other causes of low retention. Girls drop out because of 
early marriage, and boys drop out to seek informal employment. With multiple types of schools 
and administrative bodies involved, the system is fragmented. Low central and local institutional 
management capacity further constrains improvement and the efficient use of resources.  
 

2. 

Policy and Strategic Frameworks  

 
7. 
Policy  framework.  Bangladesh  recognizes  that  its  rising  to  middle-income  status 
depends  on  having  a  large  cadre  of  skilled  workers  calibrated  to  match  growth  and  structural 
transformation  in  the  economy.  It  further  acknowledges  that  the  workforce  needs  to  have 
excellent analytical and creative thinking capability. In line with government development goals, 
the  National  Education  Policy  (NEP),  2010  envisions  high-quality  and  equitable  education  to 
prepare all students for the modernizing economy. 7
 The NEP states that learners should acquire 
competency  to  compete  in  the  job  market.  It  proposes  reforms  to  secondary  education  to  (i) 
improve the teaching of science, English, mathematics, and ICT; (ii) mainstream madrasahs; (iii) 
provide  teaching  and  learning  materials  that  are  more  relevant;  (iv)  improve  examinations;  (v) 
strengthen teacher quality; and (vi) strengthen the decentralized governance and management 
of schools.  
 

                                                
7   Government of Bangladesh, Ministry of Education. 2010. National Education Policy. Dhaka.     

 

  

3 

Secondary  education  sector  road  map.  The  government  acknowledges  the  need  to 
8. 
develop  a  long-term  strategy  to  meet  demand  for  higher  quality  and  more  relevant  secondary 
education.  The  Ministry  of  Education  (MOE)  has  developed,  with  support  from  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB), a NEP implementation strategy for secondary education that draws 
on  extensive  stakeholder  consultation. 8
 MOE  has  further  developed  a  10-year  secondary 
education sector road map, 2013–2023, that builds upon the NEP implementation strategy. The 
sector  road  map  adopts  phased  implementation  of  reforms  to  modernize  curriculum, 
examinations,  and  teacher  development,  as  well  as  to  establish  and  apply  common  quality 
standards  for  secondary  schools  and  teachers.  Extensive  investment  in  ICT-based  teaching 
facilities, science laboratories and equipment, other learning materials, and teacher training will 
support these reforms. The sector road map further plans to intensify gender-equitable and pro-
poor  stipend  programs  using 
It  suggests  expanding  school 
improved  methodology. 
infrastructure  according  to  need  and  recruiting  better-qualified  teachers  with  revised  selection 
procedures.  Institutional  reform  to  decentralize  education  management  will  redefine  and 
strengthen  the  roles  and  responsibilities  of  field  offices  and  school  management  committees. 
Extensive  capacity  development  in  management  at  the  center  and  in  the  field  will  strengthen 
performance  monitoring  and  the  efficient  use  of  resources.  The  government  projects  an 
additional  3.5  million  secondary  school  students  by  2023,  to  be  accommodated  by  expanding 
teacher  ranks  by  145,000  and  the  number  of  schools  by  10,000.  Success  in  implementing 
reform  will  help  meet  parents’  and  beneficiaries’  aspirations  for  post-primary  education  that 
undergirds a better life and higher income prospects.  
 
9. 
Strategic  context. ADB has recognized since the 1990s the importance of investing in 
secondary  education  to  meet  national  development  goals  and  has  contributed  to  enhancing 
sector  capacity  through  a  number  of  projects.  The  Secondary  Education  Sector  Development 
Program,  which  will  close  in  December  2013,  has  contributed  to  curriculum  and  textbook 
revision; initiated reforms in student assessment, examinations, and performance-based school 
management;  and  helped  develop  model  madrasahs.  The  Second  Teaching  Quality 
Improvement  Project  focuses  on  secondary  teacher  development.  Lessons  from  past  and 
ongoing  projects show  that  reform  intended to  improve  the quality  and  relevance  of  education 
requires  extensive  efforts  to  sustain  and  gain  from  it.  The  proposed  investment  program  will 
build upon Secondary Education Sector Development Program achievements and complement 
the  Second  Teaching  Quality  Improvement  Project.  It  will  support  the  secondary  education 
sector road map. This aligns with the country partnership strategy, which emphasizes stepped 
up support to secondary education reform,9 and ADB’s corporate strategy for education, which 
prioritizes investment in post-primary education.10
  
 

3. 

Key Features   

 
10. 
Long-term  programmatic  approach. The MFF will allow ADB to establish a long-term 
partnership with the government to support the systemic reforms envisioned in the road map.11
 
ADB will support physical and other investments in a flexible manner to optimize the pace of the 
reforms.  This  approach  will  be  particularly  important  to  the  decentralization  of  education 
management, which requires complex organizational reform and extensive institutional capacity 
strengthening. As such, the MFF is more suitable than a stand-alone project.

Use  of  disbursement-linked  indicators.  The  investment  program  will  use  DLIs  as 
11. 
incentives to achieve sector results, building upon the successful experience of the PEDP III.12 
Loan disbursement will be subject to evidence of DLI achievement. The investment program will 
further  use  the  government’s  treasury  for  disbursement  and  financial  management.  It  will 
develop  a  structured  fiduciary  oversight  arrangement  to  mitigate  risk  and  strengthen 
stakeholders’  oversight  capacity.  This  arrangement  will  help 
financial 
management  and  strengthen  awareness  of  good  governance  and  sector  resistance  to 
corruption.  This  will  encourage  ADB  and  other  development  partners  to  move  to  a  more 
advanced financing modality that fully relies on results for financing.13
 A lesson from the PEDP 
III is that DLIs are powerful tools for shifting attention from inputs  to achieving essential results 
that  deliver  quality  education.  This  demonstrates  that  in  a  large  system  with  multiple 
stakeholders such as in Bangladesh, strengthening stakeholders’ incentives and accountability 
toward achieving priority results is more effective than focusing on inputs. It further shows that 
aligning  with  and  helping  the  country  system  improve  will  yield  more  positive  and  sustainable 
development effects than introducing a parallel system.  
            
Transition  to  a  sector-wide  approach.  Secondary education is currently managed by 
12. 
the  Directorate  of  Secondary  and  Higher  Education  (DSHE)  through  22  projects  under  the 
medium-term  budget  framework.  Though  projects  may  contribute  to  meeting  sector  outcomes 
within  their  limited  scope,  sector  planning  and  management  is  fragmented  and  weakened  by 
overreliance  on  external  project  implementation  units.  The  investment  program  will  support  a 
phased  transition  to  a  sector-wide  approach  with  (i)  all  projects  aligned  with  a  common 
secondary education program framework by 2017, and the number of parallel projects and their 
implementation  units  gradually  decreased  by  2023;  (ii)  institutional  capacity  in  the  MOE,  the 
DSHE, other implementing agencies, and field offices strengthened in regard to functions such 
as  planning,  monitoring  and  evaluation  (M&E),  procurement,  finance,  and  fiduciary  oversight; 
and (iii) development partners’ contributions harmonized and aligned with the country system.14
    

 
Impact and Outcome 

Outputs  

The  impact  will  be  the  increased  employability  of  secondary  education  graduates.  The

training. Two activities to introduce advanced teaching modalities will be piloted:

D.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Economic and Financial 

 
A. 
 
23. 
The economic viability of the investment program has been assessed based on overall 
return on education, analyzed using Bangladesh household and income expenditure surveys in 
2005  and  2010  and  a  cost–benefit  analysis  for  projects  1  and  2.  The  underlying  economic 
benefit  will  derive  from  improved  internal  efficiency  reflecting  reduced  dropout  and  repetition 
rates  and  from  higher  wages  for  secondary  education  graduates,  who  will  obtain  better 
employment, probably in the formal sector. Costs include investment program and private costs 
that  comprise  direct  household  outlays  and  opportunity  costs.  The  economic  internal  rate  of 
return was calculated at 18.8% for 4 years. A sensitivity analysis using low and high scenarios 
for progress in internal efficiency and external efficiency gains gives economic internal rates of 
return  ranging  from  13.9%  to  23.5%,  which  suggests  that  the  investment  program  is 
economically very sound.  
 
24. 
Fiscal sustainability will depend on three factors: (i) adequate budget delegated to the 
MOE  to  cover  estimated  investments  and  associated  recurrent  expenditures  for  secondary 
education  as  per  the  forecast  of  the  medium-term  budget  framework,  (ii)  improved  secondary 
education efficiency as envisaged, and (iii) the institutionalization of MOE and DSHE functions 
as envisaged in the sector-wide approach road map. As proposed in the NEP, the government 
is likely to increase its budget allocation for education to enable NEP reform to take place. A DLI 
on  sector  finance  will  provide  additional  incentive  for  the  Ministry  of  Finance  to  allocate  an 
adequate  annual  budget  for  secondary  education  in  line  with  medium-term  budget  framework 
forecasts. Enhanced institutional capacity in the MOE and the DSHE will ease overreliance on 
external project implementation units and build confidence in sector capacity to implement and 
deliver sector results. This will encourage higher budget allocation to the sector.  
 
B. 
 
The  procurement  capacity  assessment  showed  that  the  country’s  procurement  laws 
25. 
and  procedures  have  improved  following  extensive  procurement  reform  since  2003.  The 
government  recently  launched  its  electronic  government  procurement  system,  which  will  help 
improve efficiency, transparency, and competition in procurement. At the sector level, however, 
the  MOE  needs  to  improve  procurement  practices  and  strengthen  oversight  to  ensure 
compliance  with  agreed  procurement  rules  and  procedures.  The  MOE  and  the  DSHE  rely 
heavily  on  projects  and  their  implementation  units  for  procurement.  Establishing  a  permanent 
procurement  and  finance  division  in  the  DSHE  is  thus  warranted  in  the  medium  term.  To 

Governance 

 

  

9 

Poverty and Social 

improve  capacity,  procurement  and  documentation  need  to  be  monitored  and  a  systematic 
fiduciary oversight arrangement agreed. The electronic government procurement system should 
be introduced on a priority basis. Using the assessment, measures to improve procurement and 
mitigate risk have been consolidated in a procurement and financial management action plan.  
 
26. 
The financial management assessment shows that reform of the integrated budgeting 
and  accounting  system  through  the  Strengthening  Public  Expenditure  Management  Program, 
supported  by  development  partners,  has  improved  financial  management.  The  system  is 
gradually gaining the trust of aid programs now willing to rely on it. The PEDP III has contributed 
significantly  to  improving  the  integrated  budgeting  and  accounting  system  by  introducing  new 
schemes to track uncleared advances, payment processing time, and monthly reconciliation of 
accounts.  Measures  have  been  identified  to  further  mainstream  good  practices  in  financial 
management  through  adequate  budget  execution,  improved  quality  of  financial  reporting,  and 
capacity  development  for  the  MOE  internal  audit.  These  measures  have  been  consolidated  in 
the  procurement  and  financial  management  action  plan.  Bangladesh  ranked  144  of  176 
countries  in  Transparency  International’s  corruption  perception  index  in  2012,  showing 
corruption  still  perceived  as  key  concern.  ADB’s  country  level  assessment  also  stresses  the 
need  to  improve  governance.  A  key  development  in  the  country’s  anticorruption  initiative  and 
governance  reform  is  the  National  Integrity  Strategy  approved  in  2012.  ADB’s  Anticorruption 
Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to  and  discussed  with  the  government. 
Specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary  measures  are  described  in  the  facility 
administration manual. 
 
C. 
 
27. 
The Household and Income Expenditure Survey, 2010 shows net enrollment of children 
from  poor  households  at  37%,  well  below  the  59%  for  other  households.19 Girls  have  higher 
dropout rates and lower performance in high-stakes examinations. The investment program will 
directly  benefit  students  from  poor  and  disadvantaged  families,  madrasahs,  and  girls  by 
improving  their  access  to  high-quality  education.  A  more  efficient  and  better-targeted  stipend 
program  will  help  lift  poverty  and  sociocultural  barriers  affecting  girls’  and  boys’  school 
attendance.  Project  1  is  classified  under  category  I  (gender  equity  as  a  theme). 20 Specific 
measures addressing girls’ retention and academic performance issues are in the gender action 
plan.21
